conversation.content:
You are playing game where you are buying or selling an object. There is only one object for sale/purcahse.

Player RED is going to sell one object. Player BLUE gives ZUP to buy resources.

RULES:

```
1. You must always respond with:

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):
    <player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    B) Accept the trade by saying:
    <player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
```

Here is what you have access to:
```
Object that is being bought/sold: X
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for <ZUP>. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>,
```

All the responses you send should contain the following and in this order:

```
<proposal count> [add here (inclusive of current)] </proposal count>
<my resources> [add here] </my resources>
<my goals> [add here] </my goals>
<reason> [add here] </reason>
<player answer> [add here] </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> [add here] </newly proposed trade>
<message> [add here] </message
```

Please be sure to include all.

You are a corporation, who wants to sell a product to an individual.
You are Player RED.

```
<proposal count> 1 </proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> As a corporation, I aim to make a profit from the sale of my product. However, I must also consider the willingness of the individual (Player BLUE) to pay for the product. Since the production cost was 40 ZUP, I will start by proposing a price that allows for a reasonable profit margin while leaving room for negotiation. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 50 </newly proposed trade>
<message> We have a high-quality product X that we believe will meet your needs. Our asking price is 50 ZUP, which we find reasonable considering the production costs and the value it provides. Let's negotiate if you have a different view on the price. </message>
```

<I understand the quality of the product you're offering, but as an individual buyer, I have to consider my budget. I propose 45 ZUP for the product. If that doesn't work for you, I'm open to hearing a counteroffer.> message </I understand the quality of the product you're offering, but as an individual buyer, I have to consider my budget. I propose 45 ZUP for the product. If that doesn't work for you, I'm open to hearing a counteroffer.>

<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> Player BLUE has made a counteroffer which is above the production cost, but below the initial asking price. As it is still profitable, I could consider accepting it. However, I will make a counteroffer to see if we can reach a slightly higher price, aiming for a middle ground between the initial asking price and Player BLUE's offer. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 48 </newly proposed trade>
<message> Thank you for your offer of 45 ZUP. We understand your budget concerns, so we'd like to meet you halfway. We propose a revised price of 48 ZUP for product X. This price reflects a fair compromise between our initial asking price and your offer. </message>
```

<I appreciate your willingness to negotiate and meet me halfway. However, I'd like to counter with an offer of 47 ZUP for the product. This is a bit closer to my initial offer, and I believe it's a fair price for both of us. What do you think?> message </I appreciate your willingness to negotiate and meet me halfway. <my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> Player BLUE has increased their offer to 47 ZUP, which is just 1 ZUP below my last proposal and still above the production cost. This offer is close to my previous counteroffer and it is within an acceptable profit range; therefore, it would be reasonable to accept this offer to ensure a sale and maintain good relations with the buyer for potential future business. </reason>
<player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>
<message> Your offer of 47 ZUP is acceptable to us. We believe this is a fair price for both parties involved. We are glad to have reached an agreement and look forward to future business with you. </message>
```

You are playing game where you are buying or selling an object. There is only one object for sale/purcahse.

Player RED is going to sell one object. Player BLUE gives ZUP to buy resources.

RULES:

```
1. You must always respond with:

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):
    <player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    B) Accept the trade by saying:
    <player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
